home.hero.title: Mentivio – A Gentle Space for Mental Wellness
home.hero.subtitle: Take a compassionate step towards understanding your mental health with our safe, evidence-based assessment tools and resources.
home.crisis.alert_description: If you're experiencing thoughts of self-harm or are in crisis, please reach out for immediate help. You are not alone.
home.features.title: Your Mental Wellness Toolkit
home.features.subtitle: Simple, evidence-based tools to help you understand and support your mental health
home.features.assessment.title: Self-Assessment
home.features.assessment.desc: A confidential, clinically-informed assessment to help you understand patterns in your mental wellness.
home.features.insights.title: Condition Insights
home.features.insights.desc: Learn about different mental health conditions through interactive visualizations and clear explanations.
home.features.resources.title: Mental Health Resources
home.features.resources.desc: Access trusted information, coping strategies, and support resources for various mental health topics.
home.tips.title: Simple Wellness Practices
home.tips.subtitle: Small steps you can take to support your mental health
home.tips.mindful.title: Mindful Breathing
home.tips.mindful.desc: Take 5 minutes daily to focus on your breath. Inhale for 4 counts, exhale for 6.
home.tips.detox.title: Digital Detox
home.tips.detox.desc: Schedule 30 minutes each day without screens to reduce mental clutter.
home.tips.gratitude.title: Gratitude Practice
home.tips.gratitude.desc: Write down three things you're grateful for each day to cultivate positive thinking.
home.tips.movement.title: Movement Breaks
home.tips.movement.desc: Take short walks or stretch every 60-90 minutes to refresh your mind and body.
home.professional.title: Professional Guidance Matters
home.professional.desc: Our tools are designed for education and self-awareness, not diagnosis. Always consult healthcare professionals for medical advice.
home.resources.title: Trusted Support Resources
home.resources.subtitle: National organizations offering professional mental health support
home.resources.988.title: 988 Lifeline
home.resources.988.desc: Free, confidential support available 24/7 for people in distress or crisis.
home.resources.nami.title: NAMI Helpline
home.resources.nami.desc: National Alliance on Mental Illness offers free peer support and information.
home.resources.textline.title: Crisis Text Line
home.resources.textline.desc: Free 24/7 crisis support via text message with trained crisis counselors.
home.resources.mentalgov.title: MentalHealth.gov
home.resources.mentalgov.desc: U.S. government resource for mental health information and finding help.

resources.hero-subtitle: Access reliable information about mental health conditions, treatments, and coping strategies
resources.resource1-desc: Learn about symptoms, causes, and evidence-based treatments for depression. Includes information on major depressive disorder and persistent depressive disorder.
resources.resource2-desc: Comprehensive information about different types of anxiety disorders including generalized anxiety, panic disorder, and social anxiety.
resources.resource3-desc: Explore different therapeutic approaches including CBT, DBT, psychodynamic therapy, and how to choose what's right for you.
resources.resource4-desc: Practical techniques for mindfulness, meditation, and grounding exercises to manage stress and improve mental wellbeing.
resources.resource5-desc: Information about bipolar I, bipolar II, and cyclothymic disorder. Learn about mood stabilization and management strategies.
resources.resource6-desc: Develop a personalized self-care routine with practical tips for physical, emotional, and mental wellbeing.
resources.resource7-desc: Understanding trauma responses, PTSD symptoms, and effective treatments for trauma-related disorders.
resources.resource8-desc: Information about common psychiatric medications, how they work, side effects, and what to discuss with your doctor.
resources.faq1-question: How do I know if I need professional help?
resources.faq1-answer: If your symptoms are causing significant distress, impacting your daily functioning, or if you're having thoughts of harming yourself or others, it's important to seek professional help.
resources.faq2-question: What's the difference between a psychiatrist and a psychologist?
resources.faq2-answer: Psychiatrists are medical doctors who can prescribe medication, while psychologists focus on psychotherapy and psychological testing. Both can provide therapy.
resources.faq3-question: How long does therapy typically take?
resources.faq3-answer: The duration varies depending on individual needs, the type of therapy, and the issues being addressed. Some people benefit from short-term therapy (8-12 sessions), while others may engage in longer-term treatment.
resources.faq4-answer: Research shows that online therapy can be as effective as in-person therapy for many conditions, particularly when provided by licensed professionals using evidence-based approaches.
resources.newsletter-subtitle: Subscribe to our newsletter for mental health tips, new resources, and updates
resources.support-subtitle: Comprehensive mental health resources available 24/7 for ongoing support
resources.support1-desc: Free nationwide peer-support service providing information, resource referrals and support.
resources.support2-desc: U.S. government resource for mental health information, services and treatment options.
resources.support3-desc: Find licensed therapists, psychologists, and counselors in your area for ongoing support.

anxiety-resource.hero-subtitle: Understanding different types of anxiety disorders and effective management strategies
anxiety-resource.section1-p1: Feeling anxious sometimes is a normal part of life. Many people worry about health, money, work, or family issues. But anxiety disorders involve more than temporary worry or fear.
anxiety-resource.section1-p2: For people with anxiety disorders, the anxiety doesn't go away and can get worse over time. The feelings can interfere with daily activities like job performance, schoolwork, and relationships.
anxiety-resource.stat-text: About one-third of U.S. adolescents and adults experience an anxiety disorder at some point in their lives.
anxiety-resource.section2-p1: Anxiety disorders come in different forms, each with unique characteristics:
anxiety-resource.type1-desc: Persistent and excessive worry about various aspects of daily life, often without a specific cause.
anxiety-resource.type2-desc: Recurrent, unexpected panic attacks and ongoing worry about having more attacks.
anxiety-resource.type3-desc: Intense fear of social situations where you might be judged, embarrassed, or scrutinized.
anxiety-resource.type4-desc: Irrational fear of specific objects or situations, such as heights, flying, or animals.
anxiety-resource.type5-desc: Fear of being in situations where escape might be difficult or help unavailable.
anxiety-resource.type6-desc: Excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures (more common in children).
anxiety-resource.section3-p1: Anxiety can affect both your mind and body. Here are some common signs to watch for:
anxiety-resource.symptom1: Racing heart, palpitations, or chest tightness
anxiety-resource.symptom2: Shortness of breath, hyperventilation, or feeling smothered
anxiety-resource.symptom6: Racing thoughts, difficulty concentrating, or mind going blank
anxiety-resource.symptom7: Upset stomach, nausea, or digestive issues
anxiety-resource.symptom8: Sleep problems (trouble falling or staying asleep)
anxiety-resource.symptom9: Restlessness, feeling keyed up or on edge
anxiety-resource.section4-p1: While professional treatment is important, these strategies can help manage anxiety symptoms:
anxiety-resource.strategy1-desc: Practice deep breathing exercises like 4-7-8 breathing (inhale 4 seconds, hold 7, exhale 8) to calm your nervous system.
anxiety-resource.strategy2-desc: Use the 5-4-3-2-1 method: identify 5 things you see, 4 things you feel, 3 things you hear, 2 things you smell, and 1 thing you taste.
anxiety-resource.strategy3-desc: Systematically tense and relax different muscle groups to release physical tension.
anxiety-resource.strategy4-desc: Challenge and reframe anxious thoughts by examining evidence for and against them.
anxiety-resource.strategy5-desc: Practice staying present without judgment, observing thoughts and feelings as they come and go.
anxiety-resource.strategy6-desc: Regular exercise, balanced nutrition, adequate sleep, and limiting caffeine/alcohol can reduce anxiety.
anxiety-resource.section5-p1: Anxiety disorders are highly treatable. Most people benefit from professional help, which might include:
anxiety-resource.treatment1: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): The most effective therapy for anxiety disorders, helping you identify and change thinking and behavior patterns.
anxiety-resource.treatment2: Exposure Therapy: Gradually facing feared situations in a safe, controlled way to reduce fear responses.
anxiety-resource.treatment3: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT): Learning to accept anxious feelings while committing to value-based actions.
anxiety-resource.treatment4: Medication: SSRIs, SNRIs, or anti-anxiety medications can help manage symptoms, often in combination with therapy.
anxiety-resource.treatment5: Mindfulness-Based Therapies: MBCT and other mindfulness approaches can help manage anxiety symptoms.
anxiety-resource.section5-p2: Many people find that a combination of therapy and medication works best. Treatment should be tailored to your specific needs and type of anxiety disorder.
anxiety-resource.section6-p1: If anxiety is interfering with your daily life, reaching out for help is an important step toward feeling better.
anxiety-resource.section6-p2: Start with your primary care doctor - they can rule out other medical conditions that might cause similar symptoms and refer you to mental health specialists.
anxiety-resource.section6-p3: Consider seeing a mental health professional such as a psychiatrist, psychologist, or licensed therapist who specializes in treating anxiety disorders.
anxiety-resource.source-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH). For more detailed information, visit

bipolar-resource.hero-subtitle: Understanding mood disorders, stabilization strategies, and comprehensive treatment approaches
bipolar-resource.section1-p1: Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition characterized by extreme mood swings that include emotional highs (mania or hypomania) and lows (depression). These mood changes go beyond normal ups and downs and can significantly impact daily functioning.
bipolar-resource.stat-text: Bipolar disorder affects approximately 5.7 million adult Americans, or about 2.6% of the U.S. population.
bipolar-resource.section1-p2: While everyone experiences mood changes, people with bipolar disorder have shifts that are more severe, last longer, and interfere with their ability to work, maintain relationships, and function in daily life.
bipolar-resource.section2-p1: There are several types of bipolar disorder, each with distinct patterns of mood episodes:
bipolar-resource.type1-desc: Defined by manic episodes that last at least 7 days, or by manic symptoms so severe that immediate hospital care is needed. Depressive episodes typically last at least 2 weeks.
bipolar-resource.type1-feature: At least one manic episode is required for diagnosis.
bipolar-resource.type2-desc: Defined by a pattern of depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes, but not the full-blown manic episodes of Bipolar I.
bipolar-resource.type2-feature: Hypomanic episodes are less severe than manic episodes but still noticeable changes from normal behavior.
bipolar-resource.type3-desc: Defined by periods of hypomanic symptoms and depressive symptoms lasting for at least 2 years in adults (1 year in children).
bipolar-resource.type3-feature: Symptoms are less severe but more chronic than other types.
bipolar-resource.section3-p1: Bipolar disorder involves distinct episodes of mood changes. Understanding these episodes is key to recognizing the condition:
bipolar-resource.manic-symptom2: Decreased need for sleep without feeling tired
bipolar-resource.manic-symptom5: Impulsive or risky behavior (spending, sex, business decisions)
bipolar-resource.manic-note: Note: Hypomania is a less severe form of mania that doesn't cause major problems in daily functioning.
bipolar-resource.depressive-symptom2: Loss of interest in activities once enjoyed
bipolar-resource.depressive-symptom3: Significant changes in appetite or weight
bipolar-resource.depressive-symptom4: Sleeping too much or too little
bipolar-resource.depressive-symptom6: Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
bipolar-resource.feature1-desc: Symptoms of both mania and depression occurring simultaneously - often described as the most difficult part of bipolar disorder
bipolar-resource.feature2-desc: Experiencing four or more mood episodes within a single year
bipolar-resource.feature3-desc: In severe episodes, may include hallucinations or delusions that match the mood state
bipolar-resource.section4-p1: Bipolar disorder is a lifelong condition, but effective treatment can help manage symptoms and enable people to live healthy, productive lives. Treatment typically involves a combination of approaches:
bipolar-resource.treatment1-item1: Mood Stabilizers: Lithium, Valproate, Lamotrigine - help prevent mood episodes
bipolar-resource.treatment1-item2: Atypical Antipsychotics: Olanzapine, Quetiapine, Risperidone - manage manic and depressive symptoms
bipolar-resource.treatment1-item3: Antidepressants: Used cautiously with mood stabilizers to avoid triggering mania
bipolar-resource.treatment1-item4: Anti-anxiety medications: For managing anxiety symptoms
bipolar-resource.treatment1-note: Medication must be taken consistently and monitored regularly by a healthcare provider.
bipolar-resource.treatment2-item1: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Identify and change negative thought patterns
bipolar-resource.treatment2-item2: Interpersonal and Social Rhythm Therapy (IPSRT): Stabilize daily rhythms and routines
bipolar-resource.treatment2-item3: Family-Focused Therapy: Involve family in treatment and education
bipolar-resource.treatment2-item4: Psychoeducation: Learn about the illness and management strategies
bipolar-resource.treatment3-item1: Sleep Regulation: Maintain consistent sleep schedule
bipolar-resource.treatment3-item2: Stress Management: Regular exercise, meditation, relaxation techniques
bipolar-resource.treatment3-item3: Mood Tracking: Use journals or apps to monitor symptoms
bipolar-resource.treatment3-item4: Substance Avoidance: Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs
bipolar-resource.treatment3-item5: Healthy Routine: Consistent daily schedule for meals, activities, sleep
bipolar-resource.treatment-success: With proper treatment, most people with bipolar disorder can achieve significant symptom reduction and improved quality of life. However, it often takes time to find the right combination of treatments.
bipolar-resource.section5-p1: Recognizing early warning signs and having a crisis plan can help prevent severe episodes and ensure prompt treatment:
bipolar-resource.prevention1-item1: Decreased need for sleep without feeling tired
bipolar-resource.prevention1-item6: Changes in appetite or sleep patterns
bipolar-resource.prevention2-item1: Create a crisis plan with your treatment team
bipolar-resource.prevention2-item2: Share warning signs with trusted family/friends
bipolar-resource.prevention2-item4: Know when to seek immediate medical help
bipolar-resource.source-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) and Cleveland Clinic. For more detailed information, visit

depression-resource.hero-subtitle: A comprehensive guide to recognizing, understanding, and finding help for depression
depression-resource.section1-p1: We all feel sad or down sometimes, but these feelings usually pass after a while. Depression is different—it's a serious medical condition that affects how you feel, think, and handle daily activities.
depression-resource.section1-p2: Depression isn't just "feeling blue." It can cause intense emotional pain and make it hard to function at work, school, or in relationships. The good news is that depression is treatable, and most people who seek help get better.
depression-resource.section1-p3: Depression can affect anyone regardless of age, gender, background, or life circumstances. It results from a combination of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors.
depression-resource.section2-p1: Depression shows up differently in different people, but here are some common signs to watch for:
depression-resource.symptom1: Persistent sad, anxious, or empty feelings
depression-resource.symptom2: Sleep problems (too much or too little)
depression-resource.symptom4: Loss of energy or increased fatigue
depression-resource.symptom5: Trouble thinking, concentrating, or making decisions
depression-resource.symptom8: Loss of interest in activities you once enjoyed
depression-resource.section2-p2: If you've experienced several of these symptoms for more than two weeks, it might be time to talk to a healthcare provider.
depression-resource.section3-p1: Depression isn't one-size-fits-all. There are several types, each with its own characteristics:
depression-resource.type1-desc: Severe symptoms that interfere with daily life, lasting at least two weeks.
depression-resource.type2-desc: Less severe but longer-lasting depression (two years or more).
depression-resource.type3-desc: Depression that occurs during specific seasons, usually winter.
depression-resource.type4-desc: Depression during pregnancy or after childbirth (postpartum).
depression-resource.type5-desc: Severe depression accompanied by hallucinations or delusions.
depression-resource.section4-p1: Depression is highly treatable. Most people benefit from professional help, which might include:
depression-resource.treatment2-note: Medication can take 4-8 weeks to show full effects
depression-resource.section4-p2: Many people find that a combination of treatments works best. What helps one person might not work for another, so it's important to work with a healthcare provider to find the right approach for you.
depression-resource.section5-p1: If you think you might be experiencing depression, reaching out for help is a sign of strength, not weakness.
depression-resource.section5-p2: Start with your primary care doctor - they can rule out other medical conditions that might cause similar symptoms and refer you to mental health specialists.
depression-resource.section5-p3: Consider seeing a mental health professional such as a psychiatrist, psychologist, or licensed therapist who specializes in treating depression.
depression-resource.section5-p4: Build a support system of trusted friends or family members who can offer emotional support during your treatment.
depression-resource.source-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH). For more detailed information, visit

mindfulness-resource.hero-subtitle: Practical techniques for stress management and improving mental wellbeing
mindfulness-resource.section1-p1: Mindfulness is the practice of purposely focusing your attention on the present moment—and accepting it without judgment. It's about being fully aware of what's happening right now, both inside you and around you.
mindfulness-resource.section1-tip-text: While mindfulness seems simple, it takes practice to develop this skill. The goal isn't to empty your mind, but to observe your thoughts and feelings without getting carried away by them.
mindfulness-resource.section1-p2: You can practice mindfulness during meditation by focusing on your breath, or you can bring mindfulness to everyday activities like walking, eating, or even talking with others.
mindfulness-resource.section2-p1: Research shows that practicing mindfulness regularly can have significant positive effects on both mental and physical health:
mindfulness-resource.benefit1: Reduces stress, anxiety, and depression symptoms
mindfulness-resource.benefit2: Lowers blood pressure and improves heart health
mindfulness-resource.benefit3: Improves sleep quality and reduces insomnia
mindfulness-resource.benefit6: Supports healthier eating habits and weight management
mindfulness-resource.research-highlight-text: Mindfulness-based treatments have been proven effective for reducing anxiety and depression. Studies also show it can help prevent relapse of depression by helping people "de-center" from negative thoughts.
mindfulness-resource.section3-p1: Beginning a meditation practice is simpler than you might think. Here's a step-by-step guide to help you start:
mindfulness-resource.step1-desc: Choose a comfortable place where you won't be interrupted. You can sit on a chair, cushion, or even lie down.
mindfulness-resource.step2-desc: Start with just 5-10 minutes daily. Even short, consistent practice can make a difference.
mindfulness-resource.step3-desc: Notice the sensation of breathing in and out. Don't try to change your breathing—just observe it.
mindfulness-resource.step4-desc: When thoughts arise (and they will!), gently acknowledge them and return your attention to your breath.
mindfulness-resource.step5-desc: Don't judge your experience. There's no "right" way to meditate. The practice is in returning your attention.
mindfulness-resource.breathing-p1: Try this 4-7-8 breathing technique to calm your nervous system:
mindfulness-resource.breathing-p2: Repeat this cycle 4-5 times whenever you feel stressed or anxious.
mindfulness-resource.section4-p1: You can practice mindfulness in many different ways. Here are some effective exercises to try:
mindfulness-resource.ex1-desc: Systematically focus attention on different parts of your body from head to toe, noticing any sensations without judgment.
mindfulness-resource.ex2-desc: Focus on the physical sensations of walking—the movement of your feet, the air on your skin, the sights and sounds around you.
mindfulness-resource.ex3-desc: Develop feelings of goodwill and kindness toward yourself and others by repeating positive phrases and wishes.
mindfulness-resource.ex4-desc: Pay close attention to the taste, texture, and smell of your food. Notice when you feel hungry and when you feel full.
mindfulness-resource.ex5-desc: Notice one thing you can see, hear, smell, taste, and feel. This quickly brings you into the present moment.
mindfulness-resource.ex6-desc: Recognize, Allow, Investigate, and Nurture difficult emotions as they arise without getting overwhelmed by them.
mindfulness-resource.section5-p1: Incorporate mindfulness into your daily routine with these simple practices:
mindfulness-resource.tip1: Practice mindful eating - pay attention to taste, texture, and smell of your food without distractions
mindfulness-resource.tip2: Take mindful breaks during your workday - just 60 seconds of focused breathing can reset your mind
mindfulness-resource.tip3: Use mindfulness apps for guided practice - look for evidence-based programs from reputable sources
mindfulness-resource.tip4: Incorporate mindfulness into routine activities like brushing teeth, showering, or washing dishes
mindfulness-resource.tip5: Notice your body throughout the day - check in with physical sensations and tension
mindfulness-resource.tip6: Practice single-tasking instead of multitasking - give your full attention to one thing at a time
mindfulness-resource.tip7: Keep a mindfulness journal to track your practice and notice patterns
mindfulness-resource.tip8: Join a mindfulness group or class for support and guidance from experienced practitioners
mindfulness-resource.learning-tip-text: Look for mindfulness programs from medical schools and universities. If you struggle with apps or self-guided practice, consider finding a qualified teacher to guide you.
mindfulness-resource.source-info-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Institutes of Health (NIH). For more detailed information, visit

exercises.body-scan: Body Scan: Lie down comfortably. Slowly bring attention to each part of your body from toes to head, noticing sensations without judgment.
exercises.walking: Walking Meditation: Walk slowly, noticing the sensation of your feet touching ground, the movement of your body, and your surroundings.
exercises.loving-kindness: Loving-Kindness: Repeat phrases like "May I be happy, may I be healthy" for yourself, then for others.
exercises.eating: Mindful Eating: Choose one piece of food. Examine it closely, smell it, taste it slowly, noticing all sensations.
exercises.senses: Five Senses: Notice 5 things you see, 4 things you feel, 3 things you hear, 2 things you smell, 1 thing you taste.
exercises.rain: RAIN: Recognize the emotion, Allow it to be there, Investigate it with curiosity, Nurture yourself with kindness.

medication-resource.hero-subtitle: Comprehensive guide to psychiatric medications, mechanisms, and informed treatment decisions
medication-resource.section1-p1: Psychiatric medications are tools that can help manage symptoms of mental health conditions by influencing brain chemicals called neurotransmitters. While medication can be incredibly helpful, it's most effective when combined with therapy and lifestyle changes.
medication-resource.section1-important: Important: Medications affect people differently, and it may take several tries to find the right medication with the fewest side effects. Patience and open communication with your healthcare provider are key.
medication-resource.section1-p2: This guide provides educational information to help you have informed discussions with your healthcare provider. Remember that treatment decisions should always be made in partnership with qualified medical professionals.
medication-resource.section2-p1: Understanding what to expect during medication treatment can help manage expectations and reduce frustration:
medication-resource.timeline1-desc: Initial side effects may appear, often temporary
medication-resource.timeline2-desc: Early benefits like improved sleep or appetite
medication-resource.section2-remember: Remember: Most psychiatric medications take 4-8 weeks to show their full effects. Early side effects often improve within the first few weeks.
medication-resource.section3-p1: Different types of medications work on different brain chemicals and systems. Here are the main categories:
medication-resource.class1-how: Affect neurotransmitters like serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine to improve mood, sleep, appetite, and concentration.
medication-resource.class1-type1: SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors): Fluoxetine (Prozac), Sertraline (Zoloft), Escitalopram (Lexapro)
medication-resource.class1-type4: Tricyclics: Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline (older class, used less frequently)
medication-resource.class1-uses: Primary Uses: Depression, anxiety disorders, OCD, PTSD, chronic pain
medication-resource.class2-how: Reduce anxiety symptoms by enhancing the effect of GABA, a calming neurotransmitter in the brain.
medication-resource.class2-type1: Benzodiazepines: Alprazolam (Xanax), Clonazepam (Klonopin), Lorazepam (Ativan) - short-term use
medication-resource.class2-type2: Buspirone: Non-addictive option for generalized anxiety
medication-resource.class2-type3: Beta-blockers: Propranolol (for physical anxiety symptoms like rapid heartbeat)
medication-resource.class2-type4: Certain Antidepressants: SSRIs and SNRIs are often first-line for anxiety disorders
medication-resource.class2-uses: Primary Uses: Generalized anxiety, panic disorder, social anxiety, specific phobias
medication-resource.class3-how: Help control mood swings in bipolar disorder by regulating brain activity and neurotransmitter levels.
medication-resource.class3-type1: Lithium: Gold standard for bipolar disorder, requires blood monitoring
medication-resource.class3-type3: Atypical Antipsychotics: Also used as mood stabilizers
medication-resource.class3-uses: Primary Uses: Bipolar disorder, mood swings, augmentation for treatment-resistant depression
medication-resource.class4-how: Manage symptoms of psychosis by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain. Newer agents also affect serotonin.
medication-resource.class4-type1: First-generation (Typical): Haloperidol (Haldol), Chlorpromazine - higher risk of movement side effects
medication-resource.class4-type3: Third-generation: Aripiprazole (Abilify), Brexpiprazole (Rexulti) - partial dopamine agonists
medication-resource.class4-uses: Primary Uses: Schizophrenia, bipolar mania, treatment-resistant depression, severe anxiety
medication-resource.section4-p1: Successful medication treatment involves careful management and collaboration with your healthcare team:
medication-resource.guide1-item1: Realistic Expectations: Most medications take 4-8 weeks to show full effects
medication-resource.guide1-item2: Initial Side Effects: Many temporary side effects improve within 1-2 weeks
medication-resource.guide1-item3: Dosage Adjustment: Starting with low doses and gradually increasing
medication-resource.guide1-item4: Regular Follow-ups: Close monitoring during the initial phase
medication-resource.guide1-item5: Symptom Tracking: Keep notes on benefits and side effects
medication-resource.guide2-item1: Consistent Timing: Take medications at the same time daily
medication-resource.guide2-item2: Never Stop Abruptly: Work with your doctor to taper off gradually
medication-resource.guide2-item3: Regular Monitoring: Blood tests for certain medications (lithium, valproate)
medication-resource.guide2-item4: Progress Evaluation: Regular check-ins about effectiveness
medication-resource.guide2-item5: Lifestyle Integration: Combine with therapy and healthy habits
medication-resource.guide3-item1: Full Disclosure: Share all medications and supplements you're taking
medication-resource.guide3-item2: Side Effect Reporting: Don't hesitate to discuss concerns
medication-resource.guide3-item3: Treatment Goals: Regularly review progress and adjust as needed
medication-resource.guide3-item4: Questions Preparation: Write down questions before appointments
medication-resource.guide3-item5: Honest Feedback: Share what's working and what isn't
medication-resource.section5-p1: Understanding potential risks and side effects helps you make informed decisions and recognize when to seek help:
medication-resource.safety1-item1: SSRIs/SNRIs: Nausea, headache, insomnia, sexual side effects, weight changes
medication-resource.safety1-item2: Mood Stabilizers: Weight gain, tremor, thirst, cognitive effects, hair loss
medication-resource.safety1-item3: Antipsychotics: Drowsiness, weight gain, metabolic changes, movement disorders
medication-resource.safety1-item4: Benzodiazepines: Drowsiness, dizziness, memory issues, dependency risk
medication-resource.safety1-item5: Stimulants: Decreased appetite, insomnia, increased heart rate
medication-resource.safety2-item1: Suicidal Thoughts: Especially in young adults starting antidepressants
medication-resource.safety2-item2: Serotonin Syndrome: Agitation, confusion, rapid heart rate, high temperature (emergency)
medication-resource.safety2-item3: Allergic Reactions: Rash, swelling, difficulty breathing, hives
medication-resource.safety2-item4: Severe Side Effects: Uncontrollable movements, high fever, confusion, seizures
medication-resource.safety2-item5: Mood Changes: Sudden worsening of depression or emergence of mania
medication-resource.safety3-item1: Other Medications: Always inform doctors of all prescriptions
medication-resource.safety3-item2: Supplements: St. John's Wort, SAM-e can interact with antidepressants
medication-resource.safety3-item3: Food Interactions: Grapefruit juice affects many medications
medication-resource.safety3-item4: Alcohol: Generally should be avoided with psychiatric medications
medication-resource.safety3-item5: MAOI Restrictions: Strict dietary restrictions with MAOI antidepressants
medication-resource.section6-p1: Being prepared with questions helps ensure you get the information you need to make informed treatment decisions:
medication-resource.question1: What is this medication supposed to do for my specific symptoms?
medication-resource.question2: How long will it take to see noticeable results?
medication-resource.question3: What are the most common side effects I might experience?
medication-resource.question4: Are there any serious risks or warnings I should know about?
medication-resource.question5: How long will I likely need to take this medication?
medication-resource.question6: What should I do if I miss a dose?
medication-resource.question7: Are there any foods, drinks, or activities I should avoid?
medication-resource.question8: How will we know if this medication is working effectively?
medication-resource.question9: What are the alternatives if this medication doesn't work for me?
medication-resource.question10: What is the plan for eventually stopping this medication safely?
medication-resource.question11: How does this medication interact with my other prescriptions?
medication-resource.question12: What monitoring or blood tests will I need while on this medication?
medication-resource.question13: Are there generic versions available to reduce costs?
medication-resource.question14: What should I do if I experience side effects?
medication-resource.question15: How will this medication affect my daily activities and work?
medication-resource.emergency-subtitle: Seek immediate medical help if you experience any of the following:
medication-resource.emergency1-desc: Thoughts of harming yourself or others
medication-resource.emergency3-desc: Agitation, confusion, rapid heart rate, high fever
medication-resource.emergency5-desc: Accidental ingestion of too much medication
medication-resource.emergency6-desc: Chest pain, irregular heartbeat, severe dizziness
medication-resource.emergency7-desc: Severe depression worsening or emergence of manic symptoms
medication-resource.emergency-resources: Additional Resources: Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741 • National Poison Control: 1-800-222-1222
medication-resource.modal-option1-desc: Find emergency rooms near you using GPS
medication-resource.modal-option2-desc: Enter your location to find nearby hospitals
medication-resource.modal-option2-note: Manually enter your city or zip code
medication-resource.modal-placeholder: Enter your city, zip code, or address
medication-resource.disclaimer-text: This information is for educational purposes only and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional before starting, stopping, or changing any medication regimen. Do not disregard professional medical advice or delay seeking it because of something you have read here. Medication decisions should be made in partnership with your healthcare provider based on your individual medical situation, symptoms, and treatment goals.
medication-resource.source-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) and the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI). For more detailed information, visit

ptsd-resource.hero-subtitle: Understanding trauma responses, PTSD symptoms, and evidence-based recovery approaches
ptsd-resource.section1-p1: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition that can develop after experiencing or witnessing a terrifying event. While it's normal to have upsetting memories or feel on edge after trauma, PTSD involves symptoms that persist and significantly disrupt daily life.
ptsd-resource.stat-text: About 6% of people will experience PTSD at some point in their lifetime. Women are more likely than men to develop PTSD.
ptsd-resource.section1-p2: PTSD symptoms typically begin within 3 months of the traumatic event, though they can sometimes emerge later. For a diagnosis, symptoms must last more than 1 month and be severe enough to interfere with relationships, work, or other important areas of life.
ptsd-resource.section2-p1: PTSD symptoms are grouped into four main clusters. To be diagnosed, adults must experience symptoms from all four categories for at least one month:
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item1: Flashbacks: Reliving the trauma as if it's happening again
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item2: Nightmares: Disturbing dreams related to the trauma
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item4: Emotional distress: Physical reactions to trauma reminders
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item5: Psychological distress: Intense feelings when exposed to cues
ptsd-resource.cluster2-item1: Avoiding memories: Staying away from thoughts or feelings
ptsd-resource.cluster2-item2: Avoiding reminders: Staying away from people, places, or activities
ptsd-resource.cluster2-item3: Memory gaps: Inability to recall important aspects of the trauma
ptsd-resource.cluster2-item4: Emotional numbing: Difficulty experiencing positive feelings
ptsd-resource.cluster3-item1: Negative beliefs: About oneself, others, or the world
ptsd-resource.cluster3-item2: Distorted blame: Blaming self or others for the trauma
ptsd-resource.cluster3-item3: Negative emotional state: Persistent fear, horror, anger, guilt, shame
ptsd-resource.cluster4-item3: Hypervigilance: Being overly alert to danger
ptsd-resource.cluster4-item6: Sleep disturbances: Trouble falling or staying asleep
ptsd-resource.section3-p1: Not everyone who experiences trauma develops PTSD. Various factors influence whether someone develops the condition:
ptsd-resource.risk-item1: Previous traumatic experiences, especially in childhood
ptsd-resource.risk-item2: Getting hurt or seeing people hurt or killed
ptsd-resource.risk-item3: Feeling horror, helplessness, or extreme fear
ptsd-resource.risk-item4: Little or no social support after the event
ptsd-resource.risk-item5: Additional stressors after trauma (loss, injury, job loss)
ptsd-resource.risk-item6: Personal or family history of mental illness
ptsd-resource.resilience-item1: Seeking and receiving support from others
ptsd-resource.resilience-item2: Learning to feel okay with one's actions in response
ptsd-resource.resilience-item4: Being prepared to respond to upsetting events
ptsd-resource.resilience-item7: Ability to find meaning in difficult experiences
ptsd-resource.section4-p1: PTSD treatment works. With proper care, people can learn to feel safe in the world and develop effective coping strategies. The most effective treatments are trauma-focused therapies:
ptsd-resource.treatment1-item1: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT): Helps challenge and modify unhelpful beliefs about the trauma
ptsd-resource.treatment1-item2: Prolonged Exposure Therapy (PE): Gradual exposure to trauma memories in a safe environment
ptsd-resource.treatment1-item3: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR): Uses bilateral stimulation while processing trauma
ptsd-resource.treatment1-item4: Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT): Especially effective for children and adolescents
ptsd-resource.treatment2-item1: SSRIs: Sertraline, Paroxetine, Fluoxetine (FDA-approved for PTSD)
ptsd-resource.treatment2-item4: Atypical Antipsychotics: For severe symptoms when other treatments aren't effective
ptsd-resource.treatment2-note: Note: Benzodiazepines are not recommended for PTSD treatment as they don't address core symptoms and can have serious side effects.
ptsd-resource.treatment3-item1: Yoga and Mindfulness: Body-based trauma healing and stress reduction
ptsd-resource.treatment3-item2: Acupuncture: For anxiety and stress reduction symptoms
ptsd-resource.treatment3-item3: Service Animals: Emotional support and grounding during distress
ptsd-resource.treatment3-item4: Art and Music Therapy: Non-verbal expression of trauma experiences
ptsd-resource.treatment3-item5: Group Therapy: Shared experiences and peer support
ptsd-resource.section5-p1: These techniques can help manage PTSD symptoms between therapy sessions and during moments of distress:
ptsd-resource.technique1-item1-desc: Name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, 1 thing you can taste. This brings attention to the present moment.
ptsd-resource.technique1-item2-desc: Hold an ice cube, splash cold water on your face, or hold a warm drink. The temperature change can help interrupt distressing thoughts.
ptsd-resource.technique1-item3-desc: 4-7-8 breathing: Inhale for 4 counts, hold for 7 counts, exhale for 8 counts. Repeat 4-5 times to calm the nervous system.
ptsd-resource.technique1-item4-desc: Focus on physical sensations - feel your feet on the ground, notice the chair supporting you, pay attention to your breathing.
ptsd-resource.technique2-item1-desc: Create a detailed plan for managing triggers and crisis situations. Include emergency contacts, coping strategies, and safe places.
ptsd-resource.technique2-item2-desc: Keep a journal to identify and understand your specific triggers. Note what happened before, during, and after distressing episodes.
ptsd-resource.technique2-item3-desc: Develop relationships with understanding friends, family, or support groups. Consider joining PTSD support groups for shared experiences.
ptsd-resource.technique2-item4-desc: Establish consistent routines for sleep, meals, exercise, and relaxation. Prioritize activities that bring comfort and joy.
ptsd-resource.source-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) and the National Center for PTSD. For more detailed information, visit
ptsd-resource.source-link2: National Center for PTSD Treatment Guide

selfcare-resource.hero-subtitle: Comprehensive guide to developing sustainable self-care practices for mental and emotional wellbeing
selfcare-resource.section1-p1: Self-care means taking the time to do things that help you live well and improve both your physical health and mental health. It's about actively preserving or improving your own health through intentional practices.
selfcare-resource.stat-text: 64% of Americans report engaging in self-care, and most wish they did more or want to start practicing self-care regularly.
selfcare-resource.section1-p2: Self-care is not selfish—it's essential maintenance that helps you manage stress, lower your risk of illness, and increase your energy. Even small acts of self-care in your daily life can have a big impact on your overall wellbeing.
selfcare-resource.section1-p3: Remember: Self-care should not be something you force yourself to do. It's meant to refuel you, not deplete you further.
selfcare-resource.section2-p1: Self-care should help you achieve balance across different areas of your life. SAMHSA identifies eight dimensions of wellness to focus on:
selfcare-resource.section3-p1: A comprehensive self-care practice addresses multiple aspects of your wellbeing. Here are key areas to focus on:
selfcare-resource.pillar1-desc: Activities that stimulate your mind and support mental fitness
selfcare-resource.pillar2-desc: Taking care of your body through healthy habits
selfcare-resource.pillar5-desc: Creating balance and satisfaction in work life
selfcare-resource.section4-p1: Building a sustainable self-care routine takes planning and commitment. Follow these steps to create a personalized plan:
selfcare-resource.step1-desc: Identify which areas of your life need more attention. Consider the 8 dimensions of wellness and rate your satisfaction in each area. Be honest about where you're struggling.
selfcare-resource.step2-desc: Choose 2-3 specific, achievable self-care practices to start with. Remember that small, consistent actions are more sustainable than drastic changes. Focus on what brings you joy.
selfcare-resource.step3-desc: Treat self-care activities as non-negotiable appointments. Block time in your calendar and protect this time from other commitments. Start with just 10-15 minutes daily.
selfcare-resource.step4-desc: Start your plan and regularly evaluate what's working. Be flexible and adjust your approach based on what feels most beneficial. Remember that needs change over time.
selfcare-resource.no-list-text: Create Your "No List": Identify things you'll stop doing to protect your wellbeing. This might include not checking emails after work, not overcommitting, or not engaging with negative media.
selfcare-resource.section5-p1: Here are specific self-care practices you can incorporate at different time intervals:
selfcare-resource.toolkit1-item2: Gratitude journaling (3 things you're thankful for)
selfcare-resource.toolkit1-item3: Stretching or short walk around the block
selfcare-resource.toolkit1-item7: Quick tidy of one small space
selfcare-resource.toolkit3-item4: Life goal review and planning session
selfcare-resource.section6-p1: Many people struggle to maintain consistent self-care practices. Here are common barriers and how to overcome them:
selfcare-resource.barrier1-solution: Start with micro-self-care (1-5 minute practices). Remember that self-care actually saves time by preventing burnout and improving efficiency. Schedule it like any other important appointment.
selfcare-resource.barrier2-solution: Reframe self-care as necessary maintenance, not indulgence. You can't pour from an empty cup—caring for yourself enables you to better care for others. It's like putting on your oxygen mask first on an airplane.
selfcare-resource.barrier3-solution: Begin with basic physical needs (sleep, nutrition, movement) and build from there. Use the self-assessment to identify your most urgent needs. Start small and celebrate every step.
selfcare-resource.barrier4-solution: Most effective self-care practices are free! Walking, meditation, journaling, deep breathing, and connecting with nature cost nothing. Focus on accessible practices that don't require spending money.
selfcare-resource.barrier5-title: "I feel guilty taking time for myself"
selfcare-resource.barrier5-solution: Recognize that self-care makes you more present and effective in all areas of life. It's an investment in your ability to show up fully for others. Start with small, guilt-free time blocks.
selfcare-resource.barrier6-solution: Choose restorative, low-energy self-care practices. Gentle stretching, listening to calming music, or taking a warm bath can be rejuvenating when you're exhausted.
selfcare-resource.emergency-intro: While self-care is important for maintaining mental health, it's not a substitute for professional treatment when needed. Seek professional help if you experience any of these symptoms for 2 weeks or more:
selfcare-resource.symptom1-desc: Difficulty sleeping or significant changes in sleep patterns
selfcare-resource.symptom2-desc: Changes in appetite or unplanned weight changes
selfcare-resource.symptom3-desc: Difficulty getting out of bed because of mood
selfcare-resource.symptom5-desc: Loss of interest in activities you usually enjoy
selfcare-resource.symptom6-desc: Inability to complete usual tasks and activities
selfcare-resource.symptom7-desc: Feelings of irritability, frustration, or restlessness
selfcare-resource.symptom8-desc: Thoughts of harming yourself or others
selfcare-resource.source-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) and Mental Health First Aid. For more detailed information, visit
selfcare-resource.source-link2: Mental Health First Aid Self-Care Guide

therapy-resource.hero-subtitle: Understanding different therapeutic approaches and finding what works best for you
therapy-resource.section1-p1: Psychotherapy, often called "talk therapy," is when you work with a trained therapist in a safe, confidential environment to explore your feelings, thoughts, and behaviors while learning new coping skills.
therapy-resource.section1-how-desc: During therapy sessions, you'll discuss past or current problems, experiences, thoughts, feelings, or relationships. Your therapist helps you make connections and gain insights that can lead to positive changes in your life.
therapy-resource.effectiveness-note: Research shows psychotherapy is effective for improving symptoms across many mental health conditions. Many people find the best results come from combining therapy with medication when appropriate.
therapy-resource.section2-p1: CBT focuses on the connections between your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. It helps you identify and change negative thinking patterns that contribute to emotional distress.
therapy-resource.cbt-expect-item2: Practical skills you can use daily
therapy-resource.cbt-expect-item3: Focus on current problems and solutions
therapy-resource.cbt-note: CBT has been shown to create positive changes in brain activity, improving overall functioning.
therapy-resource.section3-p1: DBT combines CBT techniques with mindfulness practices, focusing on accepting difficult feelings while working to change unhealthy behaviors.
therapy-resource.dbt-meta1: Best for: BPD, Self-harm, Suicidal thoughts
therapy-resource.section4-p1: This approach explores how past experiences and unconscious thoughts influence your current behavior and relationships.
therapy-resource.psychodynamic-approach-item4: Uses free association and dream analysis
therapy-resource.psychodynamic-meta1: Best for: Deep-seated patterns, Personality disorders
therapy-resource.section5-p1: There are many effective therapy approaches. The best one depends on your individual needs and preferences.
therapy-resource.emdr-desc: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing helps process traumatic memories through bilateral stimulation.
therapy-resource.interpersonal-desc: Focuses on improving relationships and social functioning to relieve symptoms.
therapy-resource.animal-desc: Uses trained therapy animals to reduce anxiety, depression, and provide comfort.
therapy-resource.animal-meta: Best for: Anxiety, PTSD, Hospital settings
therapy-resource.mindfulness-desc: Combines meditation and awareness practices with traditional therapy techniques.
therapy-resource.mindfulness-meta: Best for: Stress, Anxiety, Depression prevention
therapy-resource.section6-title: How to Choose the Right Therapy
therapy-resource.section6-p1: Finding the right therapy approach and therapist is key to successful treatment. Consider these factors:
therapy-resource.tip1-desc: What do you want to achieve? Symptom relief? Personal growth? Better relationships? Different therapies focus on different outcomes.
therapy-resource.tip2-desc: Look for therapies with research support for your specific concerns. CBT and DBT have strong evidence for many conditions.
therapy-resource.tip3-desc: The relationship with your therapist is crucial. You should feel comfortable, understood, and respected.
therapy-resource.tip4-desc: Consider cost, location, availability, insurance coverage, and time commitment when making your decision.
therapy-resource.choosing-note: Remember: It's okay to try different therapists or approaches until you find what works best for you. Good therapy should feel like a collaborative partnership.
therapy-resource.source-text: Source Information: This content is based on information from the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI). For more detailed information, visit

about.hero-subtitle: Creating a compassionate approach to mental health awareness and education
about.mission-statement: "Our mission is to empower individuals with knowledge, tools, and resources to better understand their mental health and take proactive steps toward wellbeing."
about.story-subtitle: How Mentivio began and our journey toward making mental health resources more accessible
about.timeline-2024-content: After my own battle with depression and loss, I realized how many people struggle silently. I witnessed friends and loved ones facing similar challenges, often feeling alone and unsure where to turn for help.
about.timeline-2025-content: I began collaborating with mental health professionals to create tools that bridge the gap between clinical care and everyday struggles. Our goal was simple: make mental health support accessible to everyone, regardless of their circumstances.
about.subtimeline-august25-content: Initial brainstorming sessions, concept development, and comprehensive data collection and cleaning to build our foundational dataset.
about.subtimeline-october25-content: Built and tested multiple ML models to find the optimal solution for developing our mental health assessment tool, focusing on accuracy and user experience.
about.subtimeline-november25-content: Integrated the ML models into a user-friendly web platform, focusing on intuitive design and accessibility for all users.
about.subtimeline-december25-content: Launched multilingual support to break down language barriers, ensuring that mental health resources are accessible and culturally resonant for a diverse global community.
about.timeline-now-content: Mentivio is my promise that no one should face their mental health journey alone. Born from personal experience, it's a platform built with compassion and understanding for anyone seeking support.
about.values-subtitle: The principles that guide everything we do at Mentivio
about.value-privacy-content: Your mental health journey is personal. We ensure complete confidentiality and data security.
about.value-empowerment-content: We provide knowledge and tools to help you make informed decisions about your wellbeing.
about.value-compassion-content: Every interaction is guided by empathy and understanding. We meet you where you are.
about.value-evidence-content: Our resources are developed with mental health professionals using current research.
about.team-founder-bio: Created Mentivio after personal experience with mental health challenges. Believes everyone deserves access to compassionate support.
about.team-advisors-bio: Licensed professionals who ensure our content is accurate, sensitive, and truly helpful for those seeking support.
about.team-community-bio: Every person who shares their story and takes steps toward understanding their mental health fuels our mission.
about.cta-subtitle: Take the first step toward understanding your mental health with our free, confidential tools

crisis.header-subtitle: Immediate help and resources when you need them most. Your safety and well-being are our priority.
crisis.emergency-subtitle: If you're experiencing severe symptoms or having thoughts of harming yourself or others, seek help immediately.
crisis.lifeline-desc: Call or text 988 — available 24/7 for free, confidential support
crisis.textline-desc: Text HOME to 741741 to connect with a trained crisis counselor
crisis.emergency-services-desc: Call 911 or go to your nearest emergency room if in immediate danger
crisis.crisis-info-title: What to Do in a Crisis
crisis.crisis-info-subtitle: Recognizing the signs and knowing how to respond can make a critical difference in a mental health emergency
crisis.recognize-content: Extreme mood swings, talking about suicide, severe anxiety, inability to perform daily tasks, or expressing hopelessness.
crisis.calm-content: Take deep breaths and try to remain calm. Your calm presence can help the person in crisis feel more secure.
crisis.listen-content: Let the person express their feelings without interrupting or offering unsolicited advice.
crisis.remove-content: If possible, remove any items that could be used for self-harm from the immediate environment.
crisis.stay-content: Stay with the person until professional help arrives or the crisis passes.
crisis.followup-content: After the immediate crisis, check in regularly and encourage ongoing professional support.
crisis.cta-subtitle: Reaching out for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Whether you're in crisis or just need someone to talk to, support is available.
crisis.search-location-desc: Enter your city or zip code
crisis.search-placeholder: Enter your city or zip code

analogy.page_title: Mental Health Analogy: Comparing Mood Disorders
analogy.analogy_hero_description0: Accurate clinical visualization of Bipolar I, Bipolar II, Depression, and normal mood states
analogy.analogy_disclaimer_text0: This visualization is for educational purposes only and is not a diagnostic tool. Mental health conditions are complex and vary between individuals.

manic: I can do anything! I don't need sleep for days!
Why is everyone so slow? I need to do everything NOW!
I'm starting three businesses today! Nothing can stop me!
I feel invincible! Let's take risks!
depressive: I can't get out of bed. Everything is pointless.
Why did I do all those things? I'm such a failure.
I wish I could just disappear forever.
I can't concentrate on anything. What's the point?
Everyone would be better off without me.

conversations0: I'm so productive! But I know this won't last...
I feel great, but something feels off...
I've accomplished so much in just a few hours!
I can't stop talking, I have so much to say!
This energy is amazing, but the crash is coming.
Everything feels heavy. I can't get out of bed.
Why does everything feel so pointless?
I wish I could just disappear.
I can't concentrate on anything. What's the point?
Everyone would be better off without me.
Today was okay. Some ups, some downs, but manageable.
I feel balanced and in control of my emotions.
Some things are challenging, but I can handle them.
I appreciate the small joys in my daily life.
I have energy for my work and personal life.

analogy.analogy_summary_bipolar1_description0: Extreme Rollercoaster - Characterized by manic episodes that may require hospitalization. The most severe form of bipolar disorder.
analogy.analogy_summary_bipolar2_description0: Mild Highs, Deep Lows - Defined by hypomanic episodes (less severe than mania) and major depressive episodes.
analogy.analogy_summary_depression_description0: Only Deep Lows - Characterized by depressive episodes only, with no history of manic or hypomanic episodes.
analogy.analogy_summary_normal_description0: Everyday Ups and Downs - Normal emotional variations that don't significantly impair functioning.
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_high_mood_content0:
Mania
• Very high energy
• Risky behavior
• Possible hospitalization
• Psychosis possible
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_high_mood_content0:
Hypomania
• Milder
• Productive
• Not psychotic
• No hospitalization needed
analogy.analogy_normal_high_mood_content0:
Normal mood variations
• Temporary happiness
• Context-appropriate
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_low_mood_content0:
Major Depression
• Severe
• Debilitating
• Often follows mania
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_low_mood_content0:
Major Depression
• Often more frequent
• Longer duration
• Primary complaint
analogy.analogy_depression_low_mood_content0:
Major Depression
• Only mood state
• No highs
• Can be severe
• Long-lasting
analogy.analogy_normal_low_mood_content0:
Sadness sometimes
• Short-term
• Proportional to events
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_energy_content0:
Extreme highs + extreme lows
• Mania: excessive energy
• Depression: very low energy
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_energy_content0:
High (hypomania) + low
• Hypomania: increased energy
• Depression: low energy
analogy.analogy_depression_energy_content0:
Mostly low
• Consistently low energy
• Fatigue common
analogy.analogy_normal_energy_content0:
Balanced, manageable
• Normal daily fluctuations
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_sleep_content0:
Little/no sleep during mania
• Feels rested despite little sleep
• Excessive sleep during depression
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_sleep_content0:
Reduced sleep during hypomania
• Less need for sleep
• Oversleeping during depression
analogy.analogy_depression_sleep_content0:
Trouble sleeping or oversleeping
• Insomnia or hypersomnia
analogy.analogy_normal_sleep_content0:
Normal variations
• Regular sleep-wake cycle
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_impact_content0:
Severe, disruptive
• Can't work during episodes
• Relationship damage
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_impact_content0:
Moderate but still disruptive
• Struggle to maintain function
• Relationships strained
analogy.analogy_depression_impact_content0:
Can be severe, long-lasting
• Work/school performance suffers
• Social withdrawal
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_diagnosis_content0:
Mania defines Bipolar I
Key Differentiator: Presence of at least one manic episode
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_diagnosis_content0:
Hypomania + Depression define Bipolar II
Key Differentiator: Hypomania (not mania) + major depression
analogy.analogy_depression_diagnosis_content0:
Only Depression (no mania/hypomania)
Key Differentiator: No history of elevated mood episodes
analogy.analogy_normal_diagnosis_content0:
Not a disorder
Key Differentiator: Normal range of human emotion

app.title: Mentivio - Mental Health Assessment Platform
app.description: Safe, clinically-informed mental health assessment and tracking

prediction.hero-description: Take a secure, clinically-informed assessment to better understand your mental well-being and receive personalized insights.
prediction.welcome-title: Welcome to the Mental Health Assessment
prediction.welcome-description: This comprehensive assessment evaluates multiple areas of mental health including mood, anxiety, sleep patterns, cognitive function, and behavioral styles. Your answers will help provide insight into your mental well-being status.
prediction.important-note-text: This assessment is for informational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. All data is securely stored on our servers to protect your privacy.
prediction.processing-description: Analyzing your responses against clinical assessment models...
prediction.review-description: Please review your answers before submitting. You can edit any answer by clicking on it.
prediction.review-note-text: To save your assessment and access history later, please enter your name and a unique patient number. You will need these details to view your assessment history next time.
prediction.normal-description: Your responses indicate typical mental health patterns with no significant clinical concerns detected across the assessed domains.
prediction.disclaimer-text: This assessment is for informational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition.
prediction.history-description: View and manage your previous assessments

questions.moodSwing: Do you experience sudden shifts in mood?
questions.sadness: Do you frequently feel sad or have a low mood?
questions.euphoric: Do you often experience feelings of euphoria or abnormally high energy?
questions.sleepDisorder: Do you regularly have trouble with sleep, such as difficulty falling or staying asleep?
questions.exhausted: Do you often feel tired or exhausted?
questions.suicidalThoughts: Have you ever had thoughts of harming yourself?
questions.aggressiveResponse: Do you become aggressive or hostile during conflicts?
questions.nervousBreakdown: Have you experienced moments of feeling emotionally overwhelmed or unable to cope?
questions.overthinking: Do you find yourself worrying or overthinking more than you'd like?
questions.anorexia: Have you noticed major changes in your appetite or eating habits?
questions.authorityRespect: Do you generally follow rules and respect authority?
questions.tryExplanation: When conflict arises, do you try to explain your point of view?
questions.ignoreMoveOn: Do you tend to avoid problems instead of addressing them?
questions.admitMistakes: Do you feel comfortable admitting when you are wrong?
questions.concentration: How would you rate your ability to concentrate?
questions.optimism: How would you describe your general outlook on life?
questions.sexualActivity: How would you describe your level of interest in sexual activity?

diagnosisDescriptions.Normal: Your responses indicate typical mental health patterns with no significant clinical concerns detected across the assessed domains.
diagnosisDescriptions.Bipolar Type-1: Your responses indicate patterns that may suggest Bipolar Type 1 disorder. This is characterized by manic episodes lasting at least 7 days.
diagnosisDescriptions.Bipolar Type-2: Your responses suggest patterns consistent with Bipolar Type 2 disorder, characterized by hypomanic and depressive episodes.
diagnosisDescriptions.Depression: Your responses are consistent with patterns often seen in depressive disorder, including persistent sadness and loss of interest.
diagnosisDescriptions.default_description: Assessment completed successfully. Please consult a medical professional for a definitive diagnosis and treatment recommendations.

alerts.selectOption: Please select an option before proceeding.
alerts.nameRequired: Please enter patient name before submitting.
alerts.noNumberConfirm: Patient number is not provided. Continue without saving to history?
alerts.loginRequired: Please enter both your name and patient number.
alerts.noHistoryFound: No assessment history found for the provided name and patient number.
alerts.deleteConfirm: Are you sure you want to delete this assessment? This action cannot be undone.
alerts.assessmentNotFound: Assessment not found. Please try reloading your history.
alerts.loadError: Error loading assessment. Please try again.
alerts.downloadError: Error downloading assessment. Please try again.
alerts.noDataForDownload: No assessment data to download. Please complete an assessment first.
alerts.displayError: Error displaying assessment details. Please try again.
alerts.configError: Assessment is still loading. Please wait a moment and try again.
alerts.loginError: Error accessing assessment history. Please try again.
alerts.deleteError: Error deleting assessment. Please try again.

name.label: Patient Name
name.title: Enter patient name (2-50 characters)
name.too_short: Name must be at least 2 characters
name.invalid_format: Name can only contain letters, spaces, hyphens, and apostrophes

age.label: Age
age.title: Enter a number between 12 and 100
age.invalid_number: Age must be a valid number

patient_number.label: Patient Number
patient_number.title: 6-20 characters with at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, and one number
patient_number.hint: 6-20 characters with uppercase, lowercase, and numbers
patient_number.too_short: Patient number must be at least 6 characters
patient_number.no_lowercase: Must include at least one lowercase letter (a-z)
patient_number.no_uppercase: Must include at least one uppercase letter (A-Z)
patient_number.no_digit: Must include at least one number (0-9)
patient_number.special_chars: Only letters and numbers allowed (no special characters)
patient_number.format_error: Must include uppercase, lowercase letters and numbers

health.message_starting: Instance is starting up, please wait

errors.assessment_id_required: Patient name, number, and assessment ID required
errors.delete_required: Patient number and assessment ID required for deletion

pdf_report.title: MENTAL HEALTH ASSESSMENT REPORT
pdf_report.question: Question
pdf_report.disclaimer_text:
This mental health assessment is provided for informational and educational purposes only. It is not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always seek the advice of your physician or qualified mental health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical or psychological condition.

If you are experiencing a mental health emergency or have thoughts of harming yourself or others, please contact emergency services immediately by calling your local emergency number or a crisis hotline.

This assessment does not constitute a clinical diagnosis and should not be used as the sole basis for making healthcare decisions.
pdf_report.footer: Confidential Mental Health Assessment Report - Generated by Clinical Assessment System

questions.moodSwing: Do you experience sudden shifts in mood?
questions.sadness: Do you frequently feel sad or have a low mood?
questions.euphoric: Do you often experience feelings of euphoria or abnormally high energy?
questions.sleepDisorder: Do you regularly have trouble with sleep, such as difficulty falling or staying asleep?
questions.exhausted: Do you often feel tired or exhausted?
questions.suicidalThoughts: Have you ever had thoughts of harming yourself?
questions.aggressiveResponse: Do you become aggressive or hostile during conflicts?
questions.nervousBreakdown: Have you experienced moments of feeling emotionally overwhelmed or unable to cope?
questions.overthinking: Do you find yourself worrying or overthinking more than you'd like?
questions.anorexia: Have you noticed major changes in your appetite or eating habits?
questions.authorityRespect: Do you generally follow rules and respect authority?
questions.tryExplanation: When conflict arises, do you try to explain your point of view?
questions.ignoreMoveOn: Do you tend to avoid problems instead of addressing them?
questions.admitMistakes: Do you feel comfortable admitting when you are wrong?
questions.concentration: How would you rate your ability to concentrate?
questions.optimism: How would you describe your general outlook on life?
questions.sexualActivity: How would you describe your level of interest in sexual activity?

diagnosisDescription.Normal: Your responses indicate a typical mental health profile with no significant clinical concerns detected.
diagnosisDescription.Bipolar Type-1: Your responses indicate patterns that may suggest Bipolar Type 1 disorder. This is characterized by manic episodes lasting at least 7 days.
diagnosisDescription.Bipolar Type-2: Your responses suggest patterns consistent with Bipolar Type 2 disorder, characterized by hypomanic and depressive episodes.
diagnosisDescription.Depression: Your responses are consistent with patterns often seen in depressive disorder, including persistent sadness and loss of interest.
diagnosisDescription.default_description: Assessment completed successfully. Please consult a medical professional for a definitive diagnosis and treatment recommendations.
